bill.summary: 10/23/2013--Passed House amended. Water Resources Reform and Development Act of 2013 - Title I: Program Reforms and Streamlining - (Sec. 101) Revises requirements for feasibility studies initiated under the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) of 1986 to: (1) limit the duration of any feasibility study to 3 years; (2) limit the cost of any such study to $3 million; and (3) require personnel of the Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) to conduct concurrent reviews of feasibility studies (currently, sequential reviews are permitted). Requires the Secretary of the Army, not later than 30 days after making a determination that a feasibility study cannot be conducted in compliance with such limitations, to: (1) prepare an updated feasibility schedule and cost estimates, (2) notify the nonfederal cost sharing partner that the feasibility study has been delayed, and (3) provide written notice to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works explaining the reasons for noncompliance. Terminates the authority for any feasibility study that is not completed within one year after the Secretary makes a determination of noncompliance. Requires the Secretary, within four years after the enactment of this Act, to report on: (1) the status of implementation of these limitations on feasibility studies, (2) the amount of time taken to complete each such feasibility study, and (3) any recommendations for additional authority to support efforts to expedite the feasibility study process. Requires the Secretary, not later than 90 days after the initiation of a feasibility study, to initiate federally-mandated reviews, including environmental reviews. (Sec. 102) Amends the WRDA of 2000 to authorize the Secretary to accept and expend funds contributed by a public utility company or natural gas company to expedite the evaluation of a permit for a water resources project or activity under the jurisdiction of the Department of the Army. (Sec. 103) Sets forth U.S. policy with respect to the importance of water resources projects and studies and the need to coordinate and expedite environmental reviews of such projects. Amends the WRDA of 2007 to designate the Corps as the federal lead agency in the environmental review process (i.e., preparation of an environmental impact statement, environmental assessment, categorical exclusion, or other document under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 [NEPA]) for a water resources project study. Requires the Corps to: (1) facilitate the expeditious resolution of the environmental review process and complete documents required by NEPA, (2) identify agencies that may have jurisdiction over a water resources project, (3) establish a plan for coordinating public and agency participation in and comment on the environmental review process for a project study, (4) identify issues of concern regarding the potential environmental or socioeconomic impacts of a project, and (5) prepare a condensed final environmental impact statement under NEPA. Requires the Secretary to survey the use by the Corps of categorical exclusions (i.e., a category of actions that do not have a significant effect on the human environment and do not require an environmental assessment or impact statement) in water resources projects. (Sec. 104) Repeals provisions of the WRDA of 1986 that require : (1) a reconnaissance study of a water resources project prior to initiating a feasibility study for such project, and (2) a review of the cost effectiveness of the design of a water resources project that has a total cost in excess of $10 million. (Sec. 105) Directs the Secretary to: (1) expedite the completion of any ongoing feasibility study for a water resources project initiated before the enactment of this Act, and (2) proceed directly to preconstruction planning, engineering, and design of the project in accordance with the WRDA of 1986 if the Secretary determines that the project is justified. (Sec. 107) Requires the Secretary to establish a process for the review of section 14 applications in a timely and consistent manner. Defines "section 14 application" as an application submitted to the Secretary requesting permission for the temporary occupation or use of a public work or the alteration or permanent occupation or use of a public work. Requires the Secretary to establish benchmark goals for review of such applications, including a 45-day benchmark for approving or disapproving a completed application and a 180-day benchmark if a completed application requires more time to review due to the type, size, cost, complexity, or impacts proposed in the application. (Sec. 108) Amends the WRDA of 1996 to authorize nonfederal interests to undertake water resources development projects that are specifically authorized by Congress. Provides that the Secretary shall be responsible for maintenance of improvements to a harbor or inland harbor constructed by a nonfederal interest if the Secretary determines, before construction, that such improvements are economically justified and environmentally acceptable, are constructed in accordance with applicable permits and appropriate engineering and design standards, and are specifically authorized by Congress. (Sec. 109) Authorizes the Secretary to accept funds from nonfederal interests toward construction of any authorized water resources project, including a project for navigation on the inland waterways. (Sec. 110) Amends the WRDA of 1992 to include the cost of operating, maintaining, and managing inland navigational facilities within the cost-sharing program for the management of recreation facilities and natural resources at water resource development projects. (Sec. 111) Amends the WRDA of 1986 to authorize the Secretary to: (1) accept funds from a nonfederal interest for any authorized water resources development project that has exceeded its maximum authorized cost under such Act; and (2) use such funds to carry out such project if the use of such funds does not increase the federal share of the cost of such project. (Sec. 112) Authorizes a nonfederal interest, subject to certain conditions and limitations, to carry out a water resources project for which a final feasibility report has been completed and authority for the Secretary to carry out such project has not been specifically authorized by Congress. (Sec. 113) Authorizes the Secretary to accept funds from other federal agencies to assess the adverse impact of the modification or construction of a water resources development project on other federal facilities. (Sec. 114) Authorizes the Secretary to carry out measures to improve fish species habitat within the boundaries and downstream of a water resources project that includes a fish hatchery if the Secretary: (1) has been explicitly authorized to compensate for fish losses associated with the project; and (2) determines that the measures are feasible, consistent with authorized project purposes and the fish hatchery, and in the public interest. (Sec. 115) Extends through 2023 the authority of the Secretary to carry out water-related planning activities that will benefit Indian tribes and that are located primarily within Indian country. Authorizes the Secretary to enter into cooperative agreements with Indian tribes to carry out activities of the Corps to protect fish, wildlife, water quality, and cultural resources. (Sec. 117) Requires the Secretary to establish a pilot program to evaluate the cost effectiveness and project delivery efficiency of allowing nonfederal interests to carry out authorized water resources development projects for coastal harbor improvement, channel improvement, inland navigation, flood damage reduction, aquatic ecosystem restoration, and hurricane and storm damage reduction. (Sec. 118) Requires the Secretary: (1) not later than February 1 of each year, to develop and submit to specified congressional committees a report to be entitled "Report to Congress on Future Water Resources Development" that identifies feasibility reports and studies and proposed modifications to an authorized water resources development project or feasibility study that meets specified criteria; and (2) not later than May 1 of each year, to publish in the Federal Register a notice requesting proposals from nonfederal interests for proposed feasibility studies and modifications to authorized water resources development projects and feasibility studies. (Sec. 119) Requires the President, as part of the President's annual budget submission to Congress, to identify and recommend Corps construction projects for which Congress should provide funding at the full level authorized for such projects and provide an explanation of the process used for making such recommendations. Requires such submission to base recommendations on the assumption that $2 billion will be appropriated for Corps construction projects for each fiscal year. Requires the Secretary to report to Congress on an inventory of all federal actions taken and a prioritization of all such actions planned to mitigate for fish and wildlife losses related to projects of the Corps in the Missouri River Basin. (Sec. 120) Requires the Secretary to make specific project recommendations to Congress as part of the study for flood and storm damage reduction required by the Disaster Relief Appropriations Act, 2013. (Sec. 121) Authorizes the Secretary to carry out a locally-preferred plan for flood risk reduction, to be paid for by nonfederal interests, if such plan is technically feasible and environmentally acceptable and the benefits of the plan exceed its costs. (Sec. 122) Directs the Secretary to: (1) review and report on the implementation of emergency provisions for restoration following a natural disaster, including flooding and hurricane damage; and (2) establish procedures for providing the public and governments affected by flooding, including Indian tribes, with timely information on expected water levels, advice regarding preparedness actions, technical assistance, and other appropriate information. (Sec. 124) Amends the National Dam Safety Program Act to: (1) include as an objective of the National Dam Safety Program the development and implementation of a comprehensive dam safety hazard education and public awareness program, and (2) allow the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to invite representatives from nongovernmental organizations to participate in meetings of the National Dam Safety Review Board. (Sec. 125) Prohibits the Secretary from implementing or enforcing any: (1) restricted area for hazardous waters at dams and other civil works structures in the Cumberland River Basin established between August 1, 2012, and the date of enactment of the Freedom to Fish Act, or (2) any new or modified area established after such date until the Secretary has complied with the requirements of such Act. (Sec. 126) Requires the Secretary to: (1) provide technical assistance to states and establish guidelines on levee safety, (2) undertake a comprehensive review of Corps policy guidelines on vegetation management for levees, and (3) allow review and comment on such guidelines. (Sec. 128) Amends the WRDA of 1992 to require the Secretary to consider the beneficial use of dredged material for purposes of regional sediment management and reducing or avoiding federal costs. (Sec. 129) Directs the Secretary to encourage: (1) advanced modeling technologies, including 3-dimensional digital modeling, for activities related to water resources development projects and studies; (2) corrosion prevention activities at water resources development projects; and (3) the use of durable, resilient, and sustainable material and practices, including the use of geosynthetic materials, advanced composites, and innovative technologies, in carrying out activities of the Corps. (Sec. 130) Directs the Secretary to submit to specified congressional committees a report on efforts to implement the use of electronic commerce in federal procurement. (Sec. 133) Directs the Secretary to conduct an assessment to determine the effects of the management practices, priorities, and authorized purposes at Corps reservoirs in arid regions on water supply during periods of drought. (Sec. 134) Amends the WRDA of 2007 to require the Secretary, for every year funds are not allocated for activities of the Corps for participating in River Basin Commissions, to submit to Congress a report on the reasons why such funds were not allocated and an analysis of the impact on specified activities of not allocating such funds. (Sec. 135) Calls on Congress to consider a water resources development bill not less than once every Congress. (Sec. 136) Recognizes the contributions of Donald G. Waldon while serving as administrator of the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway and designates a lock and dam on such Waterway as the Donald G. Waldon Lock and Dam. (Sec. 137) Amends the River and Harbor Act of 1958 to include aquatic invasive species in the program to control and eradicate aquatic plant growths. (Sec. 138) Provides that the Secretary may not prohibit the use of a floating cabin on waters under the jurisdiction of the Secretary if: (1) the floating cabin complies with regulations for recreational vessels, and (2) the Secretary has authorized the use of recreational vessels on such waters. Defines "floating cabin" as a vessel used as a means of transportation on water with overnight accommodations. (Sec. 139) Amends the WRDA of 1986 to provide for an inflation adjustment for the period beginning on November 17, 1986, and ending on the date of enactment of this Act to the amount ($200,000) of local cost-sharing requirements for all studies and projects in American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, the Virgin Islands, and the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands that the Secretary is authorized to waive. (Sec. 140) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) Congress and the Secretary should urge states to reach agreements on interstate water agreements and compacts; (2) at the request of a governor of a state, the Secretary should facilitate and assist in the development of an interstate water agreement or compact; (3) Congress should provide prompt consideration of interstate agreements and compacts; and (4) the Secretary should adopt policies and implement procedures for the operation of reservoirs that are consistent with interstate agreements and compacts. (Sec. 141) Directs the Secretary, in coordination with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), to assess and report on the effects of drought conditions on lakes that are affected by FERC-licensed reservoirs. (Sec. 142) Amends the Water Supply Act of 1958 to authorize the Secretary, not later than January 1, 2016, to accept from a state or local interest a plan for the utilization of future use water storage. Requires any such plan to include: (1) a 10-year timetable for conversion of future use storage to present use, and (2) a schedule of actions by the state or local interest to seek new and alternative users of future water storage. (Sec. 143) Declares that nothing in this Act authorizes the Secretary to carry out, at a Corps dam or reservoir, any project for a purpose not otherwise authorized as of the enactment of this Act. (Sec. 144) Directs the Director of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, in coordination with the Corps and other federal agencies, to lead a multiagency effort to slow the spread of Asian carp in the Upper Mississippi and Ohio River basin and tributaries and report on such efforts. (Sec. 145) Directs the Comptroller General (GAO) to assess and report on the federal costs of, and spending on, aquatic invasive species. (Sec. 146) Prohibits the use of programs or actions authorized by this Act to further implement coastal and marine spatial planning and ecosystem-based management components of the National Ocean Policy developed under Executive Order 13547. Requires the Secretary to submit to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation a report detailing all activities engaged in and resources expended in furtherance of Executive Order 13547 since it was issued on July 19, 2010, and any FY2014 budget requests in support of National Ocean Policy implementation. (Sec. 147) Requires any feasibility study conducted for a project for flood damage reduction or hurricane and storm damage reduction to include, as part of the calculation of benefits and costs, calculations of: (1) the anticipated reduction in flood or hurricane damage to public and private property and infrastructure resulting from completion of the proposed project; (2) anticipated direct and indirect economic benefits resulting from the completion of the proposed project; and (3) the anticipated benefits to public safety, including protection of evacuation routes. Title II: Navigation Improvements - Subtitle A: Ports - (Sec. 201) Authorizes the Secretary to use up to 5% of funds from the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund for operations and maintenance costs required by the WRDA of 1986. Sets target appropriations from the Fund, increasing each year between FY2013-FY2020, until 80% of such appropriations are used for operation and maintenance activities in FY2020. (Sec. 202) Amends the WRDA of 1986 to require the Secretary: (1) on a biennial basis, to assess and report on the operation and maintenance needs of harbors used for commercial navigation and fishing and other purposes; (2) to allocate in FY2015-FY2016 not less than 10% for the operation and maintenance costs of emerging harbors (harbors that transit less than 1 million tons of commerce annually); and (3) manage and allocate funding for all of the individually authorized projects in the Great Lakes Navigation System as components of a single, comprehensive system. (Sec. 203) Authorizes the Secretary to enter an agreement with a nonfederal interest to maintain a navigation project for a harbor or inland harbor under the WRDA of 1986. (Sec. 204) Requires the Secretary to consolidate deep draft navigation expertise within the Corps into a deep draft navigation planning center of expertise. (Sec. 205) Authorizes the Secretary to reopen the Cape Arundel Disposal Site in Maine as an alternative dredged material disposal site under the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act. Specifies the period during which such Site may remain open. (Sec. 206) Directs the Comptroller General to: (1) study and report on an evaluation of the effectiveness of activities funded by the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund in maximizing economic growth and job creation in communities surrounding low- and moderate-use ports, and (2) make recommendations for using the Fund to increase the competitiveness of U.S. ports relative to Canadian and Mexican ports. Subtitle B: Inland Waterways - (Sec. 212) Sets forth requirements for qualifying projects (i.e., any construction or major rehabilitation project for navigation infrastructure of the inland and intracoastal waterway that is authorized before, on, or after the enactment of this Act, is not completed as of the enactment of this Act, and is funded at least in part from the Inland Waterways Trust Fund), including training and certification requirements for project managers and use of a risk-based cost estimation and best management practices. Amends the WRDS of 1986 to expand the duties of the Inland Waterway Users Board to include providing advice and recommendations on the construction and rehabilitation priorities and spending levels for U.S. inland waterways and inland harbors. Requires the Secretary to submit to Congress a 20-year plan for making capital investments on the inland and intracoastal waterways. (Sec. 213) Directs the Comptroller General to prepare a report on the efficiency of collecting the fuel tax for the Inland Waterways Trust Fund. (Sec. 214) Directs the Secretary: (1) in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, to conduct a study on the feasibility of authorizing the issuance of tax-exempt bonds in the Inland Waterways Trust Fund; and (2) to conduct a study and submit to Congress a report on potential user fees and revenues from other sources that could be collected to generate additional revenues for the Inland Waterways Trust Fund. (Sec. 215) Directs the Secretary to conduct an inland waterways stakeholder roundtable to provide for a review and evaluation of alternative approaches to address the financial needs of the Inland Waterways Trust Fund and to support the water infrastructure needs of the Inland Waterways System. (Sec. 216) Requires 25% of the cost of construction for the Olmsted Project (a navigation project for Locks 52 and 53 on the Lower Ohio River between Illinois and Kentucky) to be paid from amounts appropriated from the Inland Waterways Trust Fund. Expresses the sense of Congress that the appropriation for the Project should not be less than $150 million for each fiscal year until construction of the Project is completed. Sets forth reporting requirements for the Project and any inland waterways project that has an estimated total cost of $500 million or more. (Sec. 217) Requires the Secretary, at least 90 days before carrying out a proposed modification to the operation of a lock at a project for navigation on the inland waterways, to: (1) provide notice of the proposed modification in the Federal Register, and (2) accept public comments on the proposed modification. (Sec. 218) Directs the Secretary to assess and report on the operation and maintenance needs of the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway and the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway. (Sec. 219) Directs the Secretary, not later than 180 days after the enactment of this Act, to conduct a study and report to Congress on the impact of closing the Upper St. Anthony Falls Lock and Dam in Minnesota on the economy and the environment, including an assessment of the annual average tonnage moving through such facility during the preceding 5 years. Requires the Secretary to close such facility if the annual average tonnage moving through it during the preceding 5 years was not more than 1.5 million tons. (Sec. 220) Amends the WRDA of 1986 to expand provisions authorizing the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma to design and construct hydroelectric generating facilities at the W.D. Mayo Lock and Dam on the Arkansas River, Oklahoma, including to allow the marketing of electricity generated from such facilities, establish preconstruction requirements, and provide for the allocation of costs for such facilities. Title III: Deauthorizations and Backlog Prevention - (Sec. 301) Requires the Secretary, not later than 90 days after the enactment of this Act, to submit to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works and publish in the Federal Register a list of each authorized water resources development project, or separable element of a project, authorized for construction before November 8, 2007, for which: (1) construction was not initiated before the enactment of this Act; or (2) construction was initiated but no funds were obligated during the 5-year period ending on July 1, 2013, and which has an estimated federal cost to complete of at least $12 billion. (Sec. 302) Requires the Secretary, within one year after the enactment of this Act, to conduct an assessment of all properties under the control of the Corps and develop an inventory of the properties that are not needed for the missions of the Corps. (Sec. 303) Terminates the authority for a water resources development project after the expiration of the 7-year period in which no funds have been obligated for its construction. Requires the Secretary to identify and report on such projects. (Sec. 304) Deauthorizes projects for: (1) flood protection on Walnut Creek, California; (2) navigation, Hillsborough Bay and River, Florida; (3) shoreline protection for the Kahului Wastewater Reclamation Facility, Maui, Hawaii; (4) navigation, Chicago Harbor, Illinois; (5) navigation, Illinois Waterway and Grand Calumet River, Illinois; (6) navigation, Rockland Harbor, Maine; (7) improvements on the Corsica River, Maryland; (8) navigation, Gloucester Harbor and Annisquam River, Masssachusetts; (9) navigation, Ipswich River, Massachusetts; (10) flood protection on the East Fork of the Trinity River, Texas; (11) navigation, Burnham Canal, Wisconsin; (12) navigation, Manitowoc Harbor, Wisconsin; (13) navigation, Seward Harbor, Alaska; and (14) flowage easement at Port of Hood River, Oregon. (Sec. 305) Provides for conveyances of federal land to the Tulsa Port of Catoosa, Oklahoma, and to the City of Asotin, Washington. Title IV: Water Resources Infrastructure - (Sec. 401) Authorizes final feasibility studies for water resources development and conservation and other purposes, including: (1) navigation in Texas, Louisiana, Florida, and Georgia; (2) flood risk management in Kansas, California, Iowa, Minnesota, North Dakota, and Kentucky; (3) hurricane and storm damage risk reduction in North Carolina and California; (4) hurricane and storm damage risk reduction and environmental restoration in Mississippi; and (5) environmental restoration in Maryland, Florida, Louisiana, Minnesota, and North Carolina. (Sec. 402) Modifies projects for: (1) navigation at Miami Harbor, Miami-Dade County, Florida; and (2) flood control at Little Calumet River Basin (Cady Marsh Ditch), Indiana.
